There is a lot of focus on data driven results, but I found that management was very interested in any metrics that would fit a particular narrative. Instead of utilizing the data as presented, there were times when findings that demonstrated one conclusion where disregarded or cherry-picked to fit whatever management "felt" was going on. There is a bit of art to reading data, but not nearly as much as what I felt was going on.

Additionally, Sam - the CEO - while a very kind man, and certainly very capable and smart, would also have certain "feelings" about particular strategies and objectives that may or may not be a) realistic or b) based in anything other than speculation or word of mouth. This led to a lot of employees working to simply please the CEO, rather than advocating for what was best for the company.
advice_to_mgmt:
Trust in your employees to give you actionable recommendations, and don't feel so set in your own pre-conceived notions. Especially when regarding fields that may be just out of your comfort zone.

I would also recommend that Sam invest more time in the employees who seem to be bucking popular opinion, rather than those who always fall in line.

review_title: Run for the Hills and Run as Fast as You Can
years_at_company: Run for the Hills and Run as Fast as You Can
pros: Nice people and convenient office location
cons:
Have you ever felt like you were going to drown and you thought you could save yourself until someone comes along and forces your head back underwater? That's what it feels like to work at Fareportal.

If you scroll up on this page to the "Join Us" section, you'll see several sections of them explaining why you should work at Fareportal. Here's the truth in these sections that they don't tell you. You might want to sit down as you read this:

1. We'll Help Your Career Reach New Heights: LOL. They don't actually care about your career or what your career goals are for yourself. You ask to do certain types of work to help yourself reach those goals, but instead you're given menial, busywork that really hurts your knowledge and skill level and prevents you from ever climbing the corporate ladder. It's more like sliding down the chute because you had an unfortunate roll of the dice. You can get "promoted" by them changing your title, but at this company titles mean absolutely nothing. Your job responsibilities won't change and you'll still be treated like a drone. It's like you flat line and there's no sense of revival.

2. Top-Notch Coverage: Should be more like Mediocre-Notch Coverage. If you have a family, enjoy the large amount that comes out of your paycheck. If you are single, enjoy the amount you have to pay for something that you will only use probably once a year if you are a relatively healthy person. Also, you can enjoy how a lot of doctors don't take the health insurance, but if they do, enjoy the co-pay at every appointment. Disability insurance, more like if you need to stay home from work due to a medical reason, enjoy not getting paid. Ever.

3. Time to Play: Work Hard, Play Hard. Should be Work Hard, but You're Not Working Hard Enough So No Play Time. The vacation days you get are pretty good, if you can ever get your manager to approve it. Work from home does not exist because they took away VPN access. You take a week's vacation and it feels like you never even had time to relax when you return, because it is a dark dungeon-esque creature eating away at your soul, slowly for every day of your life.

4. Here's to Your Health: Fitness classes at work, inside of a small room, with your coworkers. Sounds like a good time to me. Said no one ever. But, if you're into that then more power to you. Or, you can leave work at your designated time and go to a gym where workouts are meant to be held. Maybe that's just me, though.

5. Your Future Starts Here: Your future starts here, but will also end here if you don't make the executive life decision to leave for a different company. Competitive salaries? Where? Not here. They will low-ball you to the max and underpay you to the point where you ask yourself if it's really worth it. The answer is almost always, no, it's not worth it. The pay is WAY below industry average. The 401k is a nice benefit, but they don't match, so there's that.

6. Additional Perks: Travel discounts? I mean, if you consider $20 being a discount from a $500 flight then I guess you'd be happy. The discount doesn't even get applied to the actual ticket, it's towards the taxes & fees. Free food and drinks on the occasion are nice, though can be difficult on the digestive system if you know what I mean. The occasional drink that's served "after-hours" is nice but, in reality, who wants to actually stay after work for a beer when you can go to your home and enjoy one in the comfort of your home.

I have found myself shaking my head at this company many times. The level of disrespect some people give to others is remarkable. Your good work will go nowhere but the waiting line to the fast track to the garbage can. There is no structure, no strategy, and no chance for any kind of growth. Prepare yourself for high levels of sexism and feelings of being inferior. People are condescending and they do not care. The bathrooms are probably one of the most disgusting things I have ever used in my life. I can go on and on and on about what I don't like about this company but the world might end before I can finish. If you want to flat line in the middle of your career, this place is for you. Otherwise, run away and run the fastest you have ever ran before.
advice_to_mgmt: Do some research and change.

The culture is mostly young and energetic. It can be fun, but most times more stressful. There's another office in India that everyone has to keep tabs, and that seemed to be the source of the stress for most people here.

I always felt like if the company focused more on its brand and less on individual sales that Fareportal could be very successful.

Overall, I would say Fareportal is a good place to establish yourself, but not a good place to stay long term. Things always change though.
